qas.question: How did the Mongols acquire Chinese printing technology?

answers.text: through Kingdom of Qocho and Tibetan intermediaries
through Kingdom of Qocho and Tibetan intermediaries
through Kingdom of Qocho and Tibetan intermediaries

qas.question: When was earthenware movable type invented?
When was the Imperial Library Directorate established?

plausible_answers.text: Kingdom of Qocho and Tibetan intermediaries

qas.question: How did the Mongols acquire Japanese printing technology?
When was earthenware movable type destroyed?
When was the Imperial Library Directorate not established?

context: The Mongol rulers patronized the Yuan printing industry. Chinese printing technology was transferred to the Mongols <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>through <b5_0>Kingdom of Qocho and Tibetan intermediaries<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. Some Yuan documents such as <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>Wang Zhen<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>'s<b6_0/> Nong Shu were printed with earthenware movable type, a technology invented <a2_0>in <a2_2>the <a2_1><b7_0>12th century<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. However, most published works were still produced through traditional block printing techniques. The publication of a Taoist text inscribed with the name of <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>Töregene Khatun<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, Ögedei's wife, is one of the first printed works sponsored by the Mongols. <a4_2>In <a4_0><a4_1><b9_0>1273<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, the Mongols created the Imperial Library Directorate, a government-sponsored printing office. The Yuan government established centers for printing throughout China. Local schools and government agencies were funded to support the publishing of books.
